_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: TP-12401 Ammonia Tank and associated piping

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Pacific Ethanol Pekin, Inc.(Pacific Ethanol - Pekin) is an ethanol fuel production plant located in Pekin, in Tazewell County, Illinois.  As a requirement of the Clean Air Act Amendments 112(r) Accidental Release of Hazardous Air Substances program, Pacific Ethanol - Pekin completed a risk management plan (RMP) for any chemical stored on-site that is stored in quantities above the applicable RMP reporting threshold. This information represents a 5-year update to the current facility RMP.



Accidental Release Prevention and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Pacific Ethanol - Pekin is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process, specifically the flammable mixture natural gas condensate (RMP-regulated components:  butane, isobutane, isopentane, pentane, and propane), which may be used as the ethanol denaturant, as well as anhydrous ammonia.  The denaturant is stored in secondary containment to minimize the potential for off-site migration of spilled material and to allow for prompt response in the event of a material release.  The anhydrous ammonia is stored with process controls in place to minimize the potential for release.



It is the policy of Pacific Ethanol - Pekin to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  In the event of an emergency, including accidental release of denaturant or ammonia, it is the policy of Pacific Ethanol - Pekin to notify the Tazewell County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Pekin Fire Department and evacuate all employees at the Facility, as needed based on the extent of the emergency.



Regulated Substances Handled

The Facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn using both wet mill and dry mill processes.  The fuel ethanol production process requires use of a denaturant to render the distilled alcohol unfit for human consumption; denaturant is added to the distilled alcohol at a concentrat

ion of approximately 2 percent by volume.  Pacific Ethanol - Pekin intends uses natural gas condensate as a denaturant, which is a flammable mixture that may contain the following RMP-regulated components:  butane (4%), isobutane (1%), isopentane (35%), pentane (45%), and propane (1%).  The maximum amount of denaturant on-site is estimated to be 714,420 pounds.  The denaturant is stored in an above ground tank as a liquid and is introduced to the fuel ethanol in the final stage of production.  The denaturant tank is located in the Facility's tank farm area, which includes secondary containment.  



The Facility also stores anhydrous ammonia on-site in an above ground, pressurized bullet tank.  Anhydrous ammonia is used in the ethanol production process for pH control.  The maximum ammonia stored will be 87,000 pounds.  



Pacific Ethanol - Pekin has evaluated worst and alternative case scenarios as it relates to each of these reportable substances.  Emergency response actions for these scenarios have been prepared and implemented.  Pacific Ethanol - Pekin has coordinated emergency response with the local authorities and conducts drills.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Pacific Ethanol - Pekin maintains a consistent accidental release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases of denaturant and anhydrous ammonia. The Prevention Program required under 40 CFR 68 is very similar to the prevention program required under Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management (PSM). Pacific Ethanol - Pekin's Prevention Program 3 elements, as required under 40 CFR 68 Subpart D, are included in the facility's PSM Plan. Required elements include: 



?    Employee Participation

?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Contractors

?    Pre-startup Review

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Hot Work Permits

?    Management of Change

?    Incident Investigation

?    Compliance Audits

?    Emergency

Response

?    Trade Secrets



Five Year Accident History

Pacific Ethanol - Pekin has not had any accidents related to the RMP-regulated substances which may have caused death, injuries, environmental or property damage, evacuations or in-place sheltering in the last five years.  



Emergency Response Program

Pacific Ethanol - Pekin has chosen to maintain a written Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that provides guidance to ensure employee safety in the event of an emergency.  In general, the EAP provides procedures for employees to report a fire or other emergency; procedures for emergency evacuation; procedures to for employees who remain to operate critical plant operations prior to evacuation; contact information for employees responsible for communicating plan information; details regarding the employee alarm system; an employee training program for evacuation; and procedures for routine review and updates to the plan.



In addition, the Facility has coordinated with the Tazewell County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and is a part of the written community Emergency Response Plan. The Pekin Fire Department provides first response for all Facility emergencies.  For these reasons, Pacific Ethanol - Pekin meets the exceptions listed in 40 CFR 68.90(b) and therefore the Facility is not required to an Emergency Response Program. 



A site map, SDSs, and a list of chemicals kept on-site are maintained at the Facility. Complete details on the EAP required under the PSM Rules are included in Pacific Ethanol - Pekin's PSM Program.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Pacific Ethanol - Pekin completed a Process Hazard Analysis in September 2011.  The Facility is in the process of implementing the changes recommended during the Process Hazard Analysis and anticipates that the changes will be completed by September 2012.
